content: A new proposal has been announced: Enum Variant Types #122. It will be announced at the next meeting to try and draw attention to it, but usually MCPs are not discussed during triage meetings. If you think this would benefit from discussion amongst the team, consider proposing a design meeting.
Would it be best to close the proposal and leave a comment on the original RFC?

Uh… I think its perhaps okay to use MCP process to invoke a discussion about reviving the RFC, but making the decision on landing an implementation of a feature as major as this should go through the RFC process.
I think given that we had an RFC, and closed it as postpone but were open to reviving it in the future, I think an MCP is sufficient if we're just going to reopen and merge the existing RFC.
If we need changes, I think that would mean a new RFC PR (which could start from the existing one).
But if the RFC doesn't need changes then I think an MCP and the original RFC will suffice.
There’s also discussion in #general > Enum Variant Types

nagisa said:

This should be an RFC.

opening an initiative proposal is a REQUIRED first step for creating an RFC :)
the MCP terminology is very dated, we should fix that
(i.e., @zhamlin you are doing the right thing!)

Josh Triplett said:

If we need changes, I think that would mean a new RFC PR (which could start from the existing one).

I actually disagree, I think we need to find a liaison and make this an initiative
or, rather, I think we need a liaison etc
if indeed the old RFC is sufficient than I think re-opening it is fine
